I’m not thrilled in being part of the training of a 4-star hotel at now almost $800 per night. And I was not pleased in being gouged, especially in my own town. If staying downtown San Diego, for whatever reason, somewhere other than the Hotel Solamar would be my recommendation.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotel, but that's all it has to offer.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: After reading some other comments regarding the Hotel Solamar, I see that in most instances I was not alone. My husband and I thought we just had terrible luck, but it's obvious that this hotel still has a lot of work to do. The hotel its self is beautiful, but they seriously need more training in guest service. Upon my arrival the valet didn't help me with my luggage nor was there a bell person. At the front desk, first they couldn't find my reservation and then the girl checking me in handed me off to someone else because she was trying to check me in and do something else at the same time. Finally, after I was checked in I was not offered to have my bags brought to my room, I had to take them up myself. I read in another review that because it was his/her birthday they got a room upgrade and champagne, not so for me. Not even a "happy birthday." My husband and I ordered room service for some appetizers prior to hitting the town and were told it would be twenty minutes. Well, it never came! After going out that night we were hungry when we got back to the hotel, but it was too late to eat at there restaurant and the late night room service menu only had 3 items. We called the concierge for recommendations for late night dining and he referred us to a place that he said was open and served dinner until 1pm. When we arrived, approximatley 11:45pm, they were closing and had stopped serving dinner at 10pm. I was furious but found a place that was open and served dinner. There were little things that happened that just added up and I was not at all pleased with the service we received from this hotel's staff. I've stayed at many other hotels ranked higher and lower than Hotel Solamar and can promise that I did not receive even close to the level of service at these other hotels. I expected superior service or better from a hotel like Solamar and I was extremely disappointing especially given the amount of money you pay per night. At the end of our stay I made sure to check out at the front desk and tell them my experience, and that too was a disappointing response. I didn't want anything, per say, but I heart felt "I'm sorry" and ask for details would have been somewhat decent of them. I felt like the girl who checked me out did not care and was told by soemone else who over heard my conversation with her that they would have the General Manager contact me. A week later, no reponse. So I emailed the hotel and got a call from the Asst. GM and he was very kind and attentive. He even offered a free night to make it up to me and my husband and so we can "experience the Hotel Solamar the way it really should be experienced." He took down my address and to no surprise...over two months have gone by since that conversationa and we never received anything from him in the mail! With that said, we have no itentions of ever returning, nor refer any friends, family and especially our clients (we're local corporate business owners) to this hotel. I'd much rather pay more money and stay at a hotel, like the Omni which is not far from there, and receive far better service.

Reviews.Title: “Going to a Padres game?”
Reviews.Author: PKCinLA
Reviews.Content: If you are in town for a Padres game, the Solamar is a great option. The stadium is a block away...it's also close to 5th street in the Gaslamp. Has a modern, hip, boutique vibe reminiscent of the W chain. Nice, clean room on the 10th floor overlooking the pool/bar. Decor is trendy. Bed was great, comfortable chair, great shower. Sinks were stylish but not very functional. Service was low key. Shouldn't be an issue unless you are high maintenance. Valet parking was convenient and efficient. The pool/bar scene seemed lively but a bit touristy. They have a complimentary wine happy hour, but the wine is low grade. Get a head start on your night instead. Very good experience overall. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous!”
Reviews.Author: gretchenenders
Reviews.Content: I too went to the Solamar for a weekend getaway and we couldn't have had a more relaxing, wonderful time. The hotel is gorgeous! From the rich dark woods of the lobby to the large, funky guest rooms. Every detail was well thought out by the designers and comes together beautifully. The sun broke just as we arrived in San Diego so we were able to take full advantage of the rooftop bar/pool. You couldn't ask for a more picturesque setting. Although there wasn't a Padres game being played at the time, you could almost feel the summertime energy emitting from the baseball field across the street. You must take advantage of the wine hour as it provides for great people watching and allows you a chance to spend some time in the beautiful lobby, rather than just walking through it while coming and going. The main drag for restaurants and bars is just a block away which was a wonderful perk. All of the staff was warm and welcoming, from the moment we checked in to having beers on the pool deck, everyone was incredibly helpful and inviting. I can't wait to go back and I will highly recommend to anyone, regarless of your length of stay!

Reviews.Title: “Not pleased at all.”
Reviews.Author: brig70
Reviews.Content: This property is owned by the Kimpton Brand of hotels. Unfortunately, a far cry from the other properties in its chain. The pluses: It's definitely a "boutique" hotel that offers decent amenities and has a certain feel that appeals to a younger clientel if that's what you look for in a hotel. Every evening from 5-6pm they have a complementary wine social in the lobby. Pretty nice to unwind and relax after a long day. Also, their upstairs pool bar has a nice vibe and very comforting. I stayed at this hotel in January, and I can only assume during the warmer months, this pool bar is busy and packed with the coolest of San Diegoans. The rooms are clean and very comfortable. The bathrooms are stocked with Aveda products and the complementary morning paper greets you at the door. The hotel does have a workout room that offers a few treadmills with cable tv monitors attached, but it is small. If there is more than five people in the room it's packed. So here's why I wasn't so pleased with this hotel. When I checked in, there was nobody at the front desk. Granted, it was 9pm on a Sunday..But I feel this is the second opportunity for your hotel to make a first impression. (The first opportunity is valet, but when my cab pulled up..The valet attended looked at the cab and casually walked back in the hotel.) At the front desk, I waited about three minutes for someone to show. When they finally did, they didn't apologize for the wait nor welcome me to the hotel. The second day, I was supposed to receive a UPS Package. UPS records showed it was delivered, the hotel showed they received it, but the package was "misplaced". It was an important package I needed for a tradeshow the next day. Although the package was never found, the hotel manager did send one of his employees out to purchase a similar item for replacement. One morning, my co-workers and I sat down for breakfast. We were given coffee with our menus. It took about 20 minutes for the waiter to return. When he served our order it was wrong. He was very apologetic and comped the meal, mentioning they were short staffed that morning. It seems as if the hotel staff can make up for their shortgivings, however if you are paying $300+ a night, you shouldn't have to endure a negative experience. I've been very pleased with the Kimpton brand (Hotel Monaco in Denver and Washington, D.C.)so I expected the same level of service at this property. In their defense, it is a fairly new property. However, the hotel business isn't new. If a guest pulls up in a cab, don't walk inside. If a guest is standing at the counter for a few minutes, apologize and welcome them to the hotel. If a guest has a package sent to the hotel, don't lose it. It seems like they need to pay attention to the small details in order to make this a property worth coming back to. Since it's right in the Gaslamp District, there are many others to chose from. I doubt I would stay here again. They had an Omni attached to the ball park, so I may give that a try next time I'm in SD.

Reviews.Title: “A Place to Stay but don't Overpay”
Reviews.Author: cineart
Reviews.Content: I don't know what's up with San Diego but it seems that all the hotels in the gaslamp area are charging New York prices. The convention center is very busy with New Orleans convention overflow and any decent place within walking distance of gaslamp is charging about $300/night plus $22 parking. I decided to play Russian roulette with Hotwire and bid a four star gaslamp area hotel for $204/night +taxes (for a Thursday and Friday night stay) I got the Solamar, a new boutique hotel that bills itself as four stars. I’ve read the other reviews here and thought I’d add some comments. The staff was all top notch and I encountered no rude or sub par service as mentioned before. The lobby is well appointed and a nice place to relax and the 4th floor bar is also a nice hangout. The workout room is a joke- the smallest I’ve ever seen with about four pieces of equipment. The pool is also a ridiculous 3’ deep and therefore useless. The hotel is new so the rooms and furnishings are clean. But here is the real point of my review –value. Our room was very, very small –so small that it didn’t have the requisite ‘two chairs and a table by the window set-up’ in case you wanted to invite a guest up to your room. More importantly, the rooms were poorly insulated. Any seasoned traveler knows the awful sound of heavy fireproof hotel doors slamming early in the morning as Business Bob leaves at 6:30AM for a meeting. We could hear next-door conversations and the maid vacuuming at 8:00AM very clearly. All of this does not fit in my definition of a four star hotel. Yes the room was decorated in a funky hip style. But with the room size and noise it felt like the Solamar built regular, small and acoustically sub par rooms and then hired a decorator to do an ‘extreme makeover’ adding drapes, some funky lamps and art. That just doesn’t cut it for their regular $300/night rates. At $204 I felt neither screwed nor did I feel I got any value. If I paid just $5 more a night I might have been pissed. The lobby and bar may look four star but after all I am paying for a room. I’d stay here again but if I had to pay $300 I’d choose the Marriot Gas lamp (NOT the other Marriot monster convention hotel by the water!!) The Marriot Gas lamp may not have a basin type Kohler sink and funky drapes but the standard rooms are big, immaculate, and have an equally unique California Craftsman style about it. Hope this helps!

HotelInfo.Name: Hotel Solamar - a Kimpton Hotel
HotelInfo.Address: 435 6th Ave, San Diego, CA 92101
